questions.question: Which of the following best describes pyronaridine?
Which of the following drugs gets deposited in the retina?
questions.explanation: Chloroquine has a large volume of distribution and is deposited in the retina.Long-term use of chloroquine results in retinopathy. The classical finding is 'bull's-eyeretinopathy'

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman presented with itching and malodorous discharge in the vagina. Whiff'stest was positive and microscopy of the discharge is shown below. What is the drug of choicefor this condition?515
questions.explanation: 519The clinical scenario, a positive Whiff test and clue cells on microscopy point towards a diagnosisof bacterial vaginosis. Metronidazole (oral or intravaginal) or intravaginal clindamycin areconsidered the drugs of choice.The male partner should be treated in case of recurrent infections of bacterial vaginosis.

questions.question: Which of the following is best associated with lumefantrine?
questions.explanation: Lumefantrine is an antimalarial agent.Lumefantrine is an orally active, high efficacy; long-acting erythrocytic schizonticide relatedstructurally and acts similar to halofantrine.Lumefantrine is used only in combination with artemether.

questions.question: Suramin is indicated in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: Suramin is primarily indicated in the treatment of African trypanosomiasis. It is indicated only inthe early stages of African trypanosomiasis because of its limited entry across the blood-brainbarrier.It has no clinical utility in American trypanosomiasis. Suramin has in vitro activity againstretroviral reverse transcriptase but is ineffective in HIV infection.

questions.question: A patient presents with watery diarrhea, fever and abdominal pain. Investigations reveal aWBC count of 16,000 cells/microL. The patient has been on treatment with ampicillin for afew days. Which of the following antibiotics is approved for use in this condition?
questions.explanation: The scenario is suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis caused by Clostridium difficile andfidaxomicin is a macrocyclic antibiotic that is indicated as an alternative to vancomycin in severeand recurring Clostridium difficile infections.It acts by inhibiting protein synthesis through the blockade of RNA polymerase.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes tolnaftate?
questions.explanation: Tolnaftate is a topical synthetic antifungal agent.It distorts the mycelial growth of yeast-like fungi and molds. It is effective in the treatment ofdermatomycosis and tinea.

questions.question: A class of antibiotics that is clinically indicated in combination with penicillins is inactivatedif combined with penicillins in the same solution before administration. Identify this class ofdrugs.
questions.explanation: Aminoglycosides can be inactivated by various penicillins in vitro and thus should not be admixedin solution before administration.520Aminoglycosides and penicillin combination is indicated in several infections and they should notbe admixed in the same solution before administration.

questions.question: Which of the following antibiotics is not excreted through bile?
questions.explanation: Gentamicin is not excreted through bile. It is an aminoglycoside antibiotic and aminoglycosidesundergo minimum metabolism and are excreted almost entirely by the renal route.Erythromycin, cefoperazone, and rifampicin are excreted predominantly in bile.

questions.question: What is the mechanism of action of oseltamivir and zanamivir?
questions.explanation: Oseltamivir and zanamivir are neuraminidase inhibitors.They competitively and reversibly interact with the enzyme sites to inhibit viral neuraminidaseactivity. This interferes with the release of the progeny from infected host cells, halting the spreadof infection.Early administration hastens the resolution of symptoms if given within 48 h of infection.Oseltamivir is given at a dose of 75 mg, BD for 5 days for the treatment of Influenza A and B.For prophylaxis, it is given at a dose of 75mg, OD and continued for the duration ofexposure.

questions.question: Rifampicin can be used as first-line therapy in which of the following patients?
questions.explanation: Rifampicin is the first-line therapy and is included in the regimens for both tuberculosis andleprosy.Doxycycline combined with rifampicin is considered a first-line agent for brucellosis.

questions.question: Which of the following drugs gets deposited in cornea?
questions.explanation: Chloroquine, an anti-malarial drug may get deposited in the cornea leading to corneal opacity.Ocular toxicity of chloroquine:• Short-term therapy - blurring of vision and diplopia, reversible on stoppage of drug.• Long-term use (high-dose):•Keratopathy.Pigmentary retinopathy• Optic atrophyHydroxychloroquine has lower ocular toxicity compared to chloroquine.521Drugs causing corneal opacity:⚫ Amiodarone•• Phenothiazine• Indomethacin•⚫ ChloroquineLong-term treatment with these drugs can cause a whorl-like opacity in the corneal epitheliumcalled cornea verticillata. It is also seen in Fabry's disease.

questions.question: Which of the following is an inhibitor of RNA synthesis?
questions.explanation: Rifampicin is an inhibitor of RNA synthesis. It binds to the beta subunit of DNA dependentRNA-polymerase (rpoB) to form a stable drug-enzyme complex. The binding suppresses the chainformation in RNA synthesis.Option A: 5-Fluorouracil inhibits thymidylate synthesis.Option C: Nitrofurantoin produces highly reactive intermediates that cause DNA damageOption D: Novobiocin is a potent inhibitor of bacterial DNA gyrase.522
